name: Deligne conjecture
rephrased: The conjecture, now a theorem, states that the special value of an L-function associated with a motive, when evaluated at a specific 'critical' integer, is equal to the determinant of the period matrix of that motive.
implication_form: If a motive exists and its L-function is evaluated at a critical integer, then the value of the L-function equals the determinant of the motive's period matrix.
solved_by: The conjecture was proven by mathematicians (various proofs exist for the different formulations, e.g., related to the Kashiwara-Schapira work for the operad part and others for the L-function part).
explained: Deligne's conjecture primarily addresses two interconnected aspects. First, it proposes a formula relating the absolute value of an L-function associated with a motive (a fundamental object in arithmetic geometry) at a positive integer (the 'special value') to an invariant derived from the Hodge structure (period matrix) of that motive. This relates to the broader conjectures about special values of L-functions. Second, it states that the Hochschild cochain complex of an associative algebra naturally carries the structure of a dg-algebra over the operad of chains of the little disks operad. This second part has been proven, while the first part concerning L-functions is more deeply rooted in the theory of motives and Hodge structures.
